page.title: A Young Man Being Introduced to the Seven Liberal Arts

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Sandro Botticelli 028.jpg | title=A Young Man Being Introduced to the Seven Liberal Arts | artist=Sandro Botticelli | year=1483–1486 | type=Fresco, detached and mounted on canvas | height_metric=237 | width_metric=269 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in |city=Paris | museum=[[Musée du Louvre]] }} '''''A Young Man Being Introduced to the Seven Liberal Arts''''', also known as '''''Lorenzo Tornabuoni Presented by Grammar to Prudentia and the other Liberal Arts''''' or '''''Lorenzo Tornabuoni Being Introduced to the Liberal Arts''''' ({{lang-it|Giovane Introdotto tra le Arti Liberali}}), is a painting by the Italian [[Renaissance]] painter [[Sandro Botticelli]], circa 1483-1486. The painting and its companion piece, [[Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman (Botticelli)|''Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman'']], originally decorated Villa Lemmi, a country villa near [[Florence]] owned by [[Giovanni Tornabuoni]], uncle of [[Lorenzo de' Medici]] and head of the Roman branch of the [[Medici]] Bank. They were probably commissioned for the 1486 wedding of Giovanni's son Lorenzo to Giovanna of the [[Albizzi]] family, and are therefore thought to depict the two.<ref name=deimlink>{{cite book|title=Sandro Botticelli 1444/5 - 1510|last=Deimling|first=Barbara|publisher=Taschen|location=Cologne, Germany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VjHEhT5wRiwC|year=2007|isbn=978-3-8228-5992-6|page=12}}</ref>
''A Young Man Being Introduced to the Seven Liberal Arts'' depicts a young man, perhaps Lorenzo Tornabuoni, led by a personification of [[Grammar]] into a circle of allegorical figures representing the [[Seven Liberal Arts]]. Presided over by [[Prudence|Prudentia]], the circle also includes [[Rhetoric]], [[Logic]], [[Arithmetic]], [[Geometry]], [[Astronomy]] and [[Music]], each recognizable by means of various attributes. In antiquity, the liberal arts denoted the education worthy of a free person and the painting therefore testifies to the young man's broad education. The figure of Arithmetic is seen holding its hand out in greeting to the young man. Tornabuoni, a scion to a banking family, would have probably had an education focused on numbers.<ref name=deimlink/>
Both paintings were discovered at Villa Lemmi in 1873 under a coat of whitewash and removed from their original location. They are currently housed in the [[Musée du Louvre]], Paris.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.louvre.fr/llv/activite/detail_parcours.jsp?CURRENT_LLV_PARCOURS%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673226925&CONTENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673226882&CURRENT_LLV_CHEMINEMENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673226882&FOLDER%3C%3Efolder_id=2534374302024407&bmLocale=en |title=Thematic Trails : Italian Renaissance Painting - The Allegory of the Liberal Arts |accessdate=July 22, 2011 |publisher=Louvre }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

page.title: Agostina Segatori Sitting in the Café du Tambourin

revision.comment: Edited reference to correct "CS1 maint: Extra text: editors list" error
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Vincent van Gogh - In the café - Agostina Segatori in Le Tambourin - Google Art Project 2.jpg | title=Agostina Segatori Sitting in the Café du Tambourin | artist=Vincent van Gogh | year=1887 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=55.5 | width_metric=46.5 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] | museum=[[Van Gogh Museum]] }} [[File:Vincent van Gogh in Paris Agostina Segatori.webm|{{largethumb}}|[[Van Gogh Museum]]'s senior researcher Louis van Tilborgh talks about the lesser known aspects of this painting.]] '''''Agostina Segatori Sitting in the Café du Tambourin''''' was painted by [[Vincent van Gogh]] in 1887. [[Agostina Segatori]] owned the [[Café du Tambourin]] that Van Gogh knew intimately. It was a gathering spot for Parisian artists, a place where their work was exhibited. Van Gogh, unable to pay in cash for his meals, exchanged paintings for his fare. The paintings then adorned the restaurant. He held a special exhibit of [[Japonaiserie (Van Gogh)|his Japanese prints]] in the café as well. His connection with Agostina and the cafe came to a sad end when she went bankrupt and van Gogh's paintings were confiscated by creditors. This painting, however, demonstrates an artistic discovery that culminated in his unique, creative style not quite on the brink of being understood and revered.
==Van Gogh's influence in Paris== In 1886 van Gogh left the Netherlands, never to return, for Paris and the guidance of his brother [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]]. He entered Paris as a shy, somber man and while his personality would never change, he emerged artistically into what one critic described as a "singing bird". While van Gogh had been influenced by great Dutch masters, coming to Paris meant that he was influenced by [[Impressionism|Impressionists]], [[Symbolists]], [[Pointillism|Pointillists]], and [[Ukiyo-e|Japanese prints]]. His circle of friends included [[Camille Pissarro]], [[Henri Toulouse-Lautrec]], [[Paul Gauguin]], [[Émile Bernard (painter)|Émile Bernard]] and others. The works of Japanese artists [[Hiroshige]] and [[Hokusai]] greatly influenced van Gogh, both for the beautiful subject matter and the style of flat patterns of colors without shadow. Van Gogh explored the various influences and molded them into a style that was uniquely his own. In the years 1886 to 1888, van Gogh emerged as a sophisticated, thoughtful and provoking artist. This painting demonstrates his journey of creativity in that period.<ref>{{cite book | title=The World of Van Gogh (1853-1890) | author=Wallace, R | publisher=Time-Life Books | location=Alexandria, VA, USA | year=1969 | pages=40, 69 }}</ref>
==The painting== In the painting Agostina, a woman in her forties, can be seen smoking a cigarette while having her second glass of beer, evidenced by two saucers under the mug of beer. In demeanor and style, such as her clothing, make-up and hairstyle, she is a modern woman. She is wearing a fashionable hat. According to the style at the time, her jacket is a different design than her dress. A parasol sits on one of the seats next to her.
Van Gogh used the theme of a woman sitting at a small table, introduced by Impressionists, such as [[Edgar Degas]] and [[Édouard Manet]]. The table and stools were in the shape of tambourines, befitting the café's theme. On the wall behind her are [[Japonaiserie (Van Gogh)|van Gogh's Japanese prints]], which he began exhibiting at the café in February 1887.<ref name="VGM">{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=3652&collection=1288&lang=en |title=In the café: Agostina Segatori in Le tambourin, 1887 |author= |date=2005–2011 |work=Permanent Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam |accessdate=March 18, 2011 | postscript=See the video on the page for more information about the painting.}}</ref><ref name="Leaf"/><ref name="Galbally"/>
[[File:Van Gogh - Portrait of Pere Tanguy 1887-8.JPG|thumb|left|''[[Portrait of Père Tanguy]],'' 1887]]The brightly colored painting and confident subject represent a shift in Van Gogh's attitude in comparison to his earlier subjects, such as his dark and tragic peasants. Even more, van Gogh's ''[[Portrait of Père Tanguy]]'' from the fall of the same year further explores his use of color and better promotes his Japanese prints.<ref>{{cite book | title=The pursuit of spiritual wisdom: the thought and art of Vincent van Gogh and Paul Gauguin | author=Maurer, N | publisher=Associated University Presses | location=Cranbury | year=1999 | origyear=1998 | page=55 | isbn=0-8386-3749-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wf_PoXKhggkC&pg=PA55 }}</ref>
==Café du Tambourin== Van Gogh occasionally visited Café du Tambourin run by Agostina Segatori, the subject of this painting. Previously an artist's model<ref name="VGM"/><ref name="Crispino">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh | author=Crispino, E | publisher=Oliver Press, Inc. | location=Minneapolis, MN | origyear=1996 | year=2008 | page=32 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G5gPqjJ9Ws4C&pg=PT18 }}</ref> to [[Édouard Manet|Manet]], [[Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot|Corot]] and others,<ref name="Leaf"/> the Naples-born Agostina saved the money she earned working as a model and opened the Italian-themed Café du Tambourin in 1885, which particularly catered to artists.<ref name="Galbally">{{cite book | title=A remarkable friendship: Vincent van Gogh and John Peter Russell | author=Galbally, A | publisher=Melbourne University Publishing | location=Australia | year=2008 | page=153 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OXpgapo52p8C&pg=PA153 }}</ref>
The café on the [[Boulevard de Clichy]] in Paris was just around the corner from the home that Vincent lived in with his brother [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]]. Besides convenience, the restaurant was notable to Van Gogh as a venue for exhibition of his paintings, a practice initiated by artists such as [[Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec]], [[Paul-Albert Besnard]] and others.<ref name="Leaf">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh's Table: At the Auberge Ravoux | first1=A | last1=Leaf | first2=F | last2=Lebain | publisher=Artisan | location=New York | year=2001 | pages=40, 44 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MBxJtWUz-CoC&pg=PA40#v=onepage&f=false | isbn=1-57965-182-8}}</ref>
In 1887 van Gogh had several meals a week at the café which were paid in paintings to adorn the restaurant's walls. He fell in love with Agostina who was twelve years older. Soon after, though, Agostina and the establishment fell on hard times. She became ill and the business, in debt and likely involved in illegal prostitution, failed. Although assured by Agostina that van Gogh could claim his paintings, according to Émile Bernard's recollection, debtors sold them<ref name="Leaf"/> "as waste canvas"<ref>{{cite book | title=The World of Van Gogh (1853-1890) | author=Wallace, R | publisher=Time-Life Books | location=Alexandria, VA, USA | year=1969 | page=70 }}</ref> in batches of 10, ranging in price from 50 [[centimes]] to one [[French franc|franc]] per bundle.<ref name="Leaf"/> Due to the bankruptcy of the cafe van Gogh lost not only the paintings, mostly [[Still life paintings by Vincent van Gogh (Paris)|still life works]] of flowers,<ref>{{cite book | title=Van Gogh's Women: Vincent's Love Affairs and Journey Into Madness | author=Fell, D | publisher=Carroll & Graf Publishers | location=New York | year=2004 | page=80 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lqSjxGgvVMMC&pg=PA80 }}</ref> but also the frames.<ref>{{cite book | title=Vincent van Gogh: A Biography | author=Meier-Graefe, J | publisher=Dover Publications | location=Mineola, New York | year=1987 | page=60 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iw7R8k5GfgMC&pg=PA60 }}</ref>
''Agostina Segatori Sitting in the Café du Tambourin'' is on display at the [[Van Gogh Museum]] in [[Amsterdam]], the [[Netherlands]].<ref name="VGM"/><ref name="Crispino"/>
==See also== {{Commons category|Agostina Segatori in Le Tambourin}} * [[Montmartre (Van Gogh series)|''Montmartre'' series]], an article about the works that Van Gogh created near the apartment that he shared with his brother and the Café du Tambourin.

[[File:Birth1776.jpg|thumb|right|300px|''Birth 1776'', oil on linen, 3.65 × 5.50 meters (12×18 feet), 1989–91]] {{italic title}} '''''America 500 Years''''' is the title of a series of paintings created in 1988–91 by [[Nabil Kanso]] in commemoration of the 500th anniversary of the discovery of America. The works in the series base their subjects on historical events in the Americas over the course of five centuries.<ref>''Nabil Kanso: The Split of Life Paintings'', pp. 103–120, NEV Editions, Atlanta, 1996</ref>
==Description== ''America 500 Years'' series of paintings comprise a wide range of works<ref>[http://america500years.com/media.html Approximately 30 works,''Visions from America'']</ref> including 9 mural-scale paintings executed in oil applied in rhythmic succession of vigorous brushwork infusing patterns and textures of varying density with intense tones of predominantly blue-black figures set against a combination of orange, red, and yellow ground.<ref>[http://america500years.com/text.html ''Kanso: America series of paintings'']</ref> The compositions divide the canvas space into distinct sections within a planar layout constituting the basis for constructing a scene of separate parts offering variations of viewpoints in their contrast between subject matter and technique.<ref>[http://america500years.com/media.html Visions from America]</ref> The pictorial organization conveys a volumetric presence of highly condensed images in juxtaposed planes expanding their irregular shaped boundaries near the top of the canvas.<ref>[http://america500years.com/text.html ''America series of paintings'']</ref> The relation between them is important for an overall understanding of the picture and its meaning.
==Paintings in the series== 1 – '''''Discovery''''' measuring {{convert|3.65|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} tall and {{convert|4.50|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} wide<ref>''America 500 Years: Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 104–105, NEV Editions, Atlanta, 1996</ref> depicts the first landing of [[Christopher Columbus]] in the [[New World]] in a scene divided in two parts corresponding to two worlds, one posed by the arrival of Columbus, the other inhabited by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|natives]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/discovery.html ''Discovery: Between Space and Time'']</ref> At the forefront of the right section stands a figure representing Columbus with a fierce look resting one hand on his sword, the other raising the cross. A silhouetted figure rises behind him with one arm raised and one stretched toward two sails above an assemblage of figures and objects that include a rearing [[horses in warfare|horse]], a figure in body [[armor]], a mariner's [[compass]], [[gunpowder]] and [[cannon]]s alluding to some of the equipments and instruments brought by Columbus.<ref>[http://america500years.com/discovery.html ''Between Space and Time'']</ref> The left part depicts an eagle and a group of figures that may represent the [[Taíno people|Taíno]] or [[Arawak peoples|Arawak]] natives, referred by Columbus as [[indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indians]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/discovery.html ''Discovery'']</ref>
2 – '''''Encounter''''' 3.65 × 5.50 meters (12 × 18 ft) depicts a scene reflecting the encounter between [[Hernán Cortés]], the Spanish [[conquistador]] and [[Montezuma II|Montezuma]], ruler of the [[Aztec empire]].<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 106–107</ref> The scene entails two sections separated by a V-shaped space formed by the intersecting fall of a figure [[warrior]] and an eagle as a [[metaphor]] for the Aztec [[Cuauhtémoc|fallen eagle]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/encounter.html ''Encounter: America Series of Paintings'']</ref> The right plane shows a dominant figure personating Cortés with a steering look reaching for his sword drawn over two struggling figures. He leans backward upon a female figure representing his interpreter and mistress known as [[la Malinche]]. The upper area shows a screaming figure with wide-flung arms arching a wild-looking horse above the figures of a priest and a soldier.<ref name="Encounter">[http://america500years.com/encounter.html ''Encounter'']</ref> The left section depicts a figure representing Montezuma holding a flower necklace. His posture orients a triangular shaped plane fitted with a group of figures, a [[Plumed Serpent|Serpent]] and objects with symbolic forms.<ref name="Encounter" />
3 – '''''Covenant''''' 3.65 × 5.50 meters (12 × 18 ft)<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 108–109</ref> depicts a scene based on the subject of the arrival in America of the early settlers known as the [[Pilgrims]] who wrote the governing [[Mayflower Compact|Compact]] aboard the [[Mayflower]] ship that landed at [[Plymouth Colony|Plymouth]]. The painting's two sections are parted at the top center by a red-yellow sun amid a whirlwind of pendulous shaped forms extending themselves over the entire picture surface.<ref>[http://america500years.com/covenant.html ''Covenant: America Series of Paintings'']</ref> At the top right side, dripping lines around the sun seem to give shape to the sail of a ship and overlap three joined figures that may refer to the signatories of the Covenant. Below them are thrusting figures reflecting [[Native Americans in the United States|natives]] appear with offerings such as plants and staples. The lower forefront shows a clergyman above a female figure leaning backward and holding in her hand a torched broom in flame alluding to the [[Salem witch trials]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/covenant.html ''Covenant'']</ref>
4 – '''''Birth 1776''''' (3.65 × 5.50 meters)<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 110–111</ref> depicts a scene on the [[American Revolution]] and [[American Independence|Independence]] in a composition that divides the canvas in two parts linked at the center by a massive tree extending its branches in all directions scattering a wild assortment of shapes suggesting "organic cells that seem to subdivide and float around the figures."<ref>[http://america500years.com/birth.html ''Birth 1776: America Series'']</ref> A fearless eagle sits at the top against a background of red and white stripes reflecting the [[American flag]] in a space dotted with stars and an image of the [[Liberty Bell]]. The area along the sides of the tree trunk shows the faces of [[George Washington]] and [[Thomas Jefferson]].<ref name="Birth 1776">[http://america500years.com/birth.html ''Birth 1776'']</ref> The left and right sections are linked by the tree trunk in establishing a unified base line projecting forms of [[muskets]] and rifles.< <ref name="Birth 1776" />
5 – '''''Branching''''' (3.65 × 5.50 meters),<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 112–113</ref> continues the motif of the tree in ''Birth 1776'' with a tripartite scene on the war of liberation and independence in Latin America depicting a "ponderous tree-trunk that builds a pathway"<ref>[http://america500years.com/branching.html ''Branching: America series'']</ref> throughout the picture. The structured planes are surrounded by light bluish space containing forms reflecting the faces of [[Simón Bolívar]], [[José de San Martín]], [[Antonio Sucre]], [[Francisco de Miranda]], [[Miguel Hidalgo]], and [[José María Morelos|José Morelos]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/branching.html ''Branching'']</ref>
6 – '''''Chains Under a Blinding Sun''''' (3 × 5.50 meters)<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 114–115</ref> is based on the subject of [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] depicting a three-part scene reflecting dark blue figures within a compressed space of deep yellow planes under a partial view of a hazy sun.<ref>[http://america500years.com/chains.html ''Chains Under a Blinding Sun: America Series'']</ref> Long pendulous shapes with circumventing rings emerge from both sides and converge at the center with dripping lines over chained and struggling figures and symbols of [[enslavement]], [[hanging]], [[lynching]], and [[torture]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/chains.html ''Chains Under a Blinding Sun'']</ref>
7 – '''''Bleeding Eagles''''' (3 × 5.50 meters)<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 116–117</ref> bases its subject on [[Native American in the United States|Native Americans]] with a scene imparting various allusions, symbolism and contrasting elements. The composition sets intense dark blue figures inside two fire-red rectangular planes whose upper parts recede outward creating a wide V-shaped central section dominated by two fighting eagles. They span their wings in a crisscross formation scattering flying feathers over a grey-white space defined by bluish flowing forms outlining drawn faces of native chiefs [[Pontiac (person)|Pontiac]], [[Chief Joseph|Joseph]], [[Cochise]], [[Crazy Horse]], [[Black Hawk (Sauk leader)|Black Hawk]], [[Red Cloud]], and [[Sitting Bull]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/eagles.html ''Bleeding Eagles: America Series of Paintings'']</ref> Above the chiefs' heads and across the upper plane, sweeping shapes of red strips with black-blue contours fuse with flowing lines of varying densities. They appear dripping over the entire image highlighting the movement and tension of the scene.<ref>[http://america500years.com/eagles.html ''Bleeding Eagles'']</ref>
8 – '''''North-South Split''''' (3.65 × 5.50) meters<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 118-119</ref> deals with the subject of the [[American Civil War]] in a scene composed in three sections demarcated at the edges by a white-bluish space that seems to widen around the upper middle part with floating forms outlining on one side the face of [[Abraham Lincoln]], and on the other, the faces of [[Robert E Lee]] and [[Stonewall Jackson]]. Their heads are turned toward the central image showing a female figure diving over a child falling between two opposing figures that personify the fighting between the [[Confederate Army|Confederate]] and [[Union Army|Union]] armies.<ref>[http://america500years.com/split.html ''North-South Split: America Series'']</ref> The right side plane is occupied by dark-blue figures surrounded by circular forms of chains breaking and loosening within the organism of a compressed space.<ref>[http://america500years.com/split.html ''North-South Split'']</ref> The left side shows figures, elements, and symbols reflecting some events that may allude to the [[Mexican–American War]].<ref>[http://america500years.com/split.html ''North-South'']</ref>
9 – '''''Glimmering Dawn''''' (3.65 × 5.50 meters)<ref>''Glory and Cruelty'', pp. 120</ref> depicts a three-part composition with an atmospheric evocation of the twentieth century. It is suggested that "the attitudes and motions of the figures and forms appear defined by webs of fire-lit strings" <ref>[http://america500years.com/dawn.html ''Glimmering Dawn: America Series'']</ref> descending from different directions with a focus at the top of the central section occupied by an umbrella shaped sphere conjuring the threat of an atomic explosion.<ref>[http://america500years.com/dawn.html ''Glimmering Dawn'']</ref> White-blue strips flowing with figure forms surround the three sections.
==See also== * ''[[The Split of Life]]''

The '''Architecture of Macau''' is the architecture that is found in [[Macau]]. Macau has diverse architecture from the casinos in its casino region to its tallest building, [[Grand Lisboa]] (which stands at 258 metres). Macau is influenced by both [[Cantonese]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] cultures.
== Background == [[Macau]] is a large city located off the south coast of [[Mainland China]], with a population of approximately 630,000 people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://worldpopulationreview.com/countries/macau-population/|title=Macau Population 2018 (Demographics, Maps, Graphs)|website=worldpopulationreview.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> and the official native languages being [[Cantonese]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. Macau is classified as a special administrative region (SAR), meaning it has separate executive, legislative and judicial systems to China. Macau was previously a Portuguese dependency, which ended in 1999 when it became autonomous<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/special-administrative-region.asp|title=Special Administrative Region - SAR|last=Staff|first=Investopedia|date=2013-01-06|work=Investopedia|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. The [[architecture]] of Macau encompasses a mixture of [[World Heritage site|world heritage]] listed and modern buildings, as well as multiple [[Bridge|bridges]] and [[Tunnel|tunnels]].
== Casinos in Macau == [[File:Casinos, Macao, 2013-08-08, DD 01.jpg|thumb|Cluster of casinos in Macau.]] Within the region of Macau, there is a total of 50 [[Casino|Casinos]] spread across the cities of Macau, [[Cotai]] and [[Taipa]]. Being known as the ‘[[Las Vegas]] of China’, Macau has a substantial amount of casinos compared to other regions, with 30 in the city of Macau, 14 in Cotai and 6 in Taipa<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.worldcasinodirectory.com/macau/casino-list|title=Macau Casino List|website=www.worldcasinodirectory.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. An example of a famous Casino in Macau is the ‘[[MGM Macau|MGM MACAU]]’, which stands at 154 metres tall<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mgm.mo/en/macau/about-us/property-overview|title=Property Overview {{!}} MGM MACAU|website=www.mgm.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> and is located near the southern coast of the northern region of Macau<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com.au/maps/place/MGM+Macau/@22.1771959,113.5362327,12.75z/data=!4m7!3m6!1s0x0:0x7bb2ff131ed87a29!5m1!1s2018-10-28!8m2!3d22.1860312!4d113.5478016|title=MGM Macau|website=MGM Macau|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. Other casinos in Macau include the [[Grand Lisboa]] Casino & Hotel, [[Wynn Macau|Wynn Casino Macau]] and [[Sands Macao|Sands Macao Hotel]], all of which are clustered around each other and near the MGM MACAU. This architectural cluster centralises the casinos near the southern coast of Macau, creating a ‘hub’ for [[gambling]] and accommodation.
== Tall buildings in Macau == Within the [[region]] of Macau, there are 20 completed buildings and 2 under construction that are above 150 metres tall, which ranks Macau as #48 in the world by number of buildings over 150 metres<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/city/macau|title=Macau - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. Macau's first building over 150m was the [[Bank of China Building, Macau|Bank of China]], which is located in the City of Macau and currently stands at 163m (535 feet) tall<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/building/bank-of-china/3179|title=Bank of China - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. [[File:Macau-Morpheus-01.jpg|thumb|188x188px|Morpheus Building, Macau.]] [[File:Grand Lisboa, Macau - panoramio.jpg|left|thumb|168x168px|[[Grand Lisboa|Grand Lisboa, Macau]].]] The tallest completed building in Macau is the Grand Lisboa Casino & Hotel, with an architectural height to the tip of 258m (846 feet) and a residential height of 197.7m (649 feet). These statistics rank the height of the building as #332 in the world. The building began construction in 2003 and was completed in 2008. Functioning as a hotel/casino and made from predominately [[steel]], [[concrete]] and [[glass]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/building/grand-lisboa/789|title=Grand Lisboa - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>, it was designed by architectural company “Dennis Lau & Ng Chun Man Architects & Engineers (HK) Ltd. (DLN)” as their 9th tallest building<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/company/110|title=Dennis Lau & Ng Chun Man Architects & Engineers (HK) Ltd. (DLN) - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The Grand Lisboa has 48 floors above ground and 4 below, with 433 [[hotel]] rooms and 338 parking spots.
Macau's most recently constructed tall building, finished in 2018, is the Morpheus building, which is a multi story building that stands at 155.2m (509 feet) tall with 40 floors above ground and 770 hotel rooms. Architecturally, the Morpheus is unconventionally constructed with an [[exoskeleton]] design and 3 separate openings that travel through the middle of the building<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/magazines/style/travel-food/article/2146778/morpheus-hotel-opens-june-city-dreams-macau|title=Morpheus hotel opens this June in City of Dreams, Macau|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The building was designed by the late [[architect]] Dame Zaha Hadid<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cityofdreamsmacau.com/en/stay/morpheus/index.html#architect|title=Morpheus Luxury {{!}} City of Dreams Macau|website=www.cityofdreamsmacau.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> and was developed by Melco Crown Entertainment Limited<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.emporis.com/statistics/tallest-buildings/city/102758/macau-china|title=Macau {{!}} Statistics {{!}} EMPORIS|last=GmbH|first=Emporis|website=www.emporis.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
Within the table below, is a list of the top 20 tallest completed buildings in Macau ranked upon structural height<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.emporis.com/statistics/tallest-buildings/city/102758/macau-china|title=Macau {{!}} Statistics {{!}} EMPORIS|last=GmbH|first=Emporis|website=www.emporis.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The amount of floors only includes above ground floors. {| class="wikitable" |+Top 20 Tallest Buildings in Macau !Rank !Building Name !Floors !Height (m) !Year |- |1 |[[Grand Lisboa]] |48 |258 |2008 |- |2 |[[L'Arc Macau]] |53 |217 |2009 |- |3 |[[Wynn Macau|Encore at Wynn Macau]] |40 |206 |2010 |- |4 |[[The Praia Block 1]] |56 |185 |2009 |- |5 |[[The Praia Block 2]] |56 |185 |2008 |- |6 |[[The Praia Block 3]] |56 |185 |2008 |- |7 |[[The Praia Block 4]] |56 |185 |2008 |- |8 |[[Mandarin Oriental Macau]] |42 |165 |2010 |- |9 |[[Bank of China Building, Macau|Bank of China Building]] |38 |163 |1991 |- |10 |[[The Buckingham Macau|The Buckingham]] |50 |160 |2009 |- |11 |[[Galaxy Macau Phase II]] |36 |160 |2015 |- |12 |[[Altira Macau]] |32 |160 |2007 |- |13 |[[Lai San Kok Macau|Lai San Kok]] |52 |156 |2008 |- |14 |[https://www.cityofdreamsmacau.com/en/stay/morpheus/index.html Morpheus] |40 |155 |2018 |- |15 |[[MGM Macau|MGM Grand Macau]] |35 |154 |2007 |- |16 |[[Studio City (Macau)|Studio City]] |32 |152 |2015 |- |17 |[[The Venetian Macao|The Venetian Macau]] |39 |151 |2007 |- |18 |[[MGM Grand Paradise]] |36 |151 |2018 |- |19 |[[Crown Towers Macau|Crown Towers]] |36 |151 |2009 |- |20 |[[Galaxy StarWorld Hotel]] |33 |148 |2006 |} [[File:Macau tower by night.jpg|thumb|[[Macau Tower]] at night.|alt=]] Technically the tallest structure in Macau, however not classified under the same category as the tallest buildings in Macau, the [[Macau Tower]] (pictured below) is 338m (1102.9 feet) tall to the tip. The tower began construction in 1998 and was opened on the 19th December, 2001. It was designed by architect, Gordon Moller and was inspired by the [[Sky Tower (Auckland)|Sky Tower in Auckland, New Zealand]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.macautower.com.mo/tower-overview/|title=Tower Overview - Macau Tower|work=Macau Tower|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. It currently holds the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] for the highest commercial [[Bungee jumping|bungy jump]] point at 233m (764 feet) and the first person to jump was film star [[Edison Chen]] (China) in 2006<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/highest-commercial-bungee-jump-facility|title=Highest commercial bungee jump facility|work=Guinness World Records|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>. [[File:West section of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge (20180902174105).jpg|thumb|West section of the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge|Zhuhai Bridge]].]]
== Bridges and tunnels == The [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge|Zhuhai Bridge]], opened in October 2018, is the world's longest sea bridge, spanning 55 kilometres (34 miles) from [[Hong Kong]] to Macau and Mainland Chinese city; Zuhai<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=China opens longest sea-crossing bridge|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>. The bridge cost approximately $20 Billion US Dollars to complete and was under construction from December 2009<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45961705|title=Quiet start for world's longest sea crossing|date=2018-10-24|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>. The bridge is designed to last over 120 years, withstanding pressures from [[Earthquake|earthquakes]] and [[Typhoon|typhoons]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/hong-kong-macau-and-zhuhai-bridge-shapes-chinas-own-silicon-valley|title=A massive bridge is set to transform southern China|website=CNBC|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. Through employing 400,000 tonnes of steel in its construction, with 30km worth of bridge above the [[Pearl River Delta]] and 7km worth of tunnel running between two [[Artificial island|artificial islands]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_01.html|title=HongKong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) : HZMB Main Bridge|website=www.hzmb.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The bridge is 3 lanes wide on each side and incorporates merging channels to transfer the traffic from the left to the right as it is technically in Chinese territory<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/worlds-longest-sea-bridge-opens-macau-hong-kong/story?id=58662116|title=World's longest sea bridge to open after 9 years of construction|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2018-10-23|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. To use the bridge, drivers from Hong Kong will need to attain special permits, of which there are only 300<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/world/2018/10/22/18010254/chain-bridge-hong-kong-macau-zhuhai|title=China’s new bridge will connect 70 million people — and give Beijing more power|work=Vox|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
[[File:Macao Friendship Bridge.jpg|left|thumb|212x212px|[[Amizade Bridge (Macau)|Point da Amizade]].]] [[File:Ponte de Sai Van.jpg|thumb|[[Sai Van Bridge|Sai Van Bridge.]]]] [[Amizade Bridge (Macau)|Point da Amizade]], which is Portuguese for the ‘friendship bridge’, connects the [[Macau Peninsula]] to Taipa Island and Pac On. With its construction beginning in June 1990, the bridge took almost 4 years to complete and was officially opened to [[Motor vehicle|motor vehicles]] in March 1994<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://macauantigo.blogspot.com/2010/05/ponte-da-amizade-desde-1994.html|title=Macau Antigo: Ponte da Amizade: desde 1994|last=Botas|first=João|date=30 May 2010|website=Macau Antigo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The bridge spans over 4.7 kilometres (2.9 miles), with a maximum height of 30 metres above the sea and is 18 metres wide at its widest point, accommodating four lanes of traffic. The bridge has two crests at different points to allow for sea traffic to travel beneath<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.jmgrating.com/index.php?m=content&c=index&a=show&catid=10&id=17|title=Ponte de Amizade Macau-Nanhai Jimu Grating|website=en.jmgrating.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The [[Sai Van Bridge]], completed in December 2004, is also a sea bridge used to connect the Macau Peninsula and Taipa Island. The full length of the bridge is 2.2km (1.37 miles) long, with its [[Tower#Transportation support|pylon]] heights standing 85 metres above ground level<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://structurae.net/structures/sai-van-bridge|title=Sai Van Bridge (Macau, 2004) {{!}} Structurae|website=Structurae|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The bridge was designed by Pengest Planeamento to accommodate both road traffic and railway carriages and is built primarily from steel, steel cables and prestressed concrete<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://structurae.net/companies/pengest-planeamento-engenharia-e-gestao-lda|title=Pengest Planeamento, Engenharia e Gestão, Lda {{!}} Structurae|website=Structurae|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The total cost of the bridge was US$70 million<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bridgeweb.com/Macaus-Sai-Van-Bridge-completed/427|title=Macau's Sai Van Bridge completed - Bridge Design & Engineering (Bd & e)|date=2004-12-21|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>.
[[File:Lotus-bridge-macau.jpg|thumb|256x256px|[[Lótus Bridge|Lotus Bridge]].]]
The smallest bridge in Macau, linking it across the border to [[Hengqin|Hengquin Island]] in Zhuhai, is the [[Lótus Bridge|Lotus Bridge]]. The bridge is approximately 900m long and its construction was completed in 1999<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://info.hktdc.com/shippers/vol23_3/vol23_3_fre03.html|title=New infrastructure enhances Macau, Zhuhai access (hktdc.com)|website=info.hktdc.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. It specifically links the Cotai reclamation area of Macau to Hengquin Island with 3 lanes either side of the bridge. The bridge cost US$25 million to construct, which was shared between the Macau and Chinese governments<ref name=":0" />. The Lotus Bridge uses an ‘asymmetric partial cloverleaf’ design<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-04-15/lotus-bridge-macau-maphead-ken-jennings|title=What Happens When Left-Hand Roads Meet Right-Hand Roads|last=Jennings|first=Ken|work=Condé Nast Traveler|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref>, which is designed to re-direct traffic onto the correct side of the road when entering their respective countries, with China being the right and Macau being the left<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/What-would-happen-on-the-border-of-a-country-that-drove-on-the-right-and-a-country-that-drove-on-the-left-How-would-you-be-able-to-drive-over-that-border|title=What would happen on the border of a country that drove on the right and a country that drove on the left? How would you be able to drive over that border? - Quora|website=www.quora.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
== Historic architecture == Most of the historic architecture and [[Landmark|landmarks]] within Macau are situated in the [[Historic Centre of Macau]], which is listed as a [[World Heritage site|UNESCO World Heritage Site]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.china-macau.com/attractions/macau-historic-center.htm|title=Macau Historic Centre - UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Macau|work=china-macau.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. As seen within the table below, there are over 20 buildings and landmarks within the Historic Centre, however in terms of historic architecture, there are a bit less than 20. Some of the architecture within the Historic Centre includes the [[Holy House of Mercy]], [[Mandarin's House|Mandarin's House]] and the [[A-Ma Temple]]. As the Historic Centre of Macau is host to both buildings and landmarks, below is a list of the historic architecture, in no particular order, with the name and year constructed included<ref name=":1" />. {| class="wikitable" |+Historic Architecture in Macau !Name !Year |- |[[Ruins of St. Paul's|The Ruins of St. Paul's Cathedral]] |1640 |- |[[Na Tcha Temple]] |1888 |- |[[Walls of Macau|Section of the Old City Walls]] |1569 |- |[[A-Ma Temple]] |1488 |- |[[Mandarin's House|Mandarin's House Macau]] |1869 |- |[[St. Lawrence's Church macau|St. Lawrence's Church]] |1560 |- |[[Fortaleza do Monte|Fortaleza do Monte (Mount Fortress)]] |1617 |- |[[Holy House of Mercy]] |1569 |- |[[St. Joseph's Seminary and Church]] |1758 |- |[[St. Augustine's Church macau|St. Augustine's Church]] |1587 |- |[[Sir Robert Ho Tung Library|Sir Robert Ho-Tung Library]] |1894 |- |[[Dom Pedro V Theatre]] |1860 |- |[[Moorish Barracks]] |1874 |- |[[Lou Kau Mansion]] |1889 |- |[[Leal Senado Building]] |1784 |- |[[Guia Fortress]] |1638 |} The Holy House of Mercy is a [[UNESCO]] World Heritage site, constructed in 1569 and situated within the Historic Centre of Macau, in the [[Senado Square]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.secretmacau.com/holy-house-of-mercy/|title=Holy House of Mercy - Secret Macau|date=2016-12-01|work=Secret Macau|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. The building was designed and constructed by D. Belchior Carneiro, following a [[Neoclassical architecture|neo-classical]] architectural trend<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://macaulifestyle.com/culture/architecture/the-holy-house-of-mercy-in-senado-square/|title=The Holy House of Mercy on Senado Square|last=Barbosa|first=Rui|date=2018-02-07|work=Macau Lifestyle|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> through incorporating 14 [[Arch|arches]] on the face and stands 2 stories high. It served as a [[Clinic|medical clinic]] for some time, later becoming an [[orphanage]]<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmm.mo/frontend/content/index.php?id=7&hl=en|title=澳門仁慈堂 - Macao Holy House of Mercy - Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macau - History|website=www.scmm.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. It is the oldest social solidarity institution in the Macau [[Special administrative regions of China|Special Administrative Region]] and has undergone multiple [[Renovation|renovations]], with the most recent in 2003 on the building's Rehabilitation Centre for the Blind<ref name=":2" />.
One of the oldest structures in and officially the oldest [[temple]] in Macau, the A-Ma Temple was built in 1488 on the southwest Macau Peninsula<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.china-macau.com/outer-harbour/a-ma-temple.htm|title=A-Ma Temple - Macau Outer Harbour Attractions|work=china-macau.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. It is made up of six separate architectural components within the entire vicinity, primarily using [[Rock (geology)|stone]], [[Brick|bricks]] and [[granite]] to build the temple. Pictured below, a notable aspect of the temple is the Gate Pavilion, which measures to be 4.5 metres wide and is made entirely from granite<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/en/site/detail/1|title=A-Ma Temple - MACAO WORLD HERITAGE|website=www.wh.mo|language=zh-cn|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
The Mandarin's House, built in 1869 and located at No. 10 Travessa de António da Silva<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/mandarinhouse/en/location/|title=Mandarin's House {{!}} Location|website=www.wh.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>, is a traditional Chinese styled compound that once housed [[Chinese literature|Chinese Literary]] personality [[Zheng Guanying|Zhen g Guanying]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/en/site/detail/4|title=Mandarin's House - MACAO WORLD HERITAGE|website=www.wh.mo|language=zh-cn|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The compound covers approximately 4,000 square metres of land and it encompasses architectural elements of [[Art Deco]] as well as traditional Chinese styling with [[Western world|Western influence]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/mandarinhouse/en/introduction/|title=Mandarin's House {{!}} Introduction|website=www.wh.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. In 2001 the Government took over the complex from its private owners and in 2005 it became a UNESCO World Heritage Site<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.secretmacau.com/mandarins-house/|title=Mandarin's House - Secret Macau|date=2016-12-17|work=Secret Macau|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>

[[File:A self-portrait by George Jamesone.jpeg|thumb|300px|Self portrait of [[George Jamesone]], 1642]] [[File:Royal Arms of Scotland, Magdalen Chapel, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|upright|Rare example of pre-Reformation stained glass in the Magdalen Chapel, Edinburgh]] '''Art in early modern Scotland''' includes all forms of artistic production within the modern borders of Scotland, between the adoption of the [[Renaissance in Scotland|Renaissance]] in the early sixteenth century to the beginnings of the [[Scottish Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] in the mid-eighteenth century.
Devotional art before the [[Scottish Reformation|Reformation]] included books and images commissioned in the [[Netherlands]]. Before the Reformation in the mid-sixteenth century the interiors of Scottish churches were often elaborate and colourful, with [[sacrament house]]s and [[Funerary art|monumental effigies]]. Scotland's ecclesiastical art paid a heavy toll as a result of Reformation [[iconoclasm]], with the almost total loss of medieval stained glass, religious sculpture and paintings.
In about 1500 the Scottish monarchy turned to the recording of royal likenesses in panel portraits. More impressive are the works or artists imported from the continent, particularly the Netherlands. The tradition of royal portrait painting in Scotland was probably disrupted by the minorities and regencies it underwent for much of the sixteenth century, but it flourished after the Reformation. [[James VI of Scotland|James VI]] employed Flemish artists [[Arnold Bronckorst]] and [[Adrian Vanson]], who have left behind a visual record of the king and major figures at the court. The first significant native artist was [[George Jamesone]], who was succeeded by a series of portrait painters as the fashion moved down the social scale to [[laird]]s and [[burgess (title)|burgess]]es.
The loss of ecclesiastical patronage that resulted from the Reformation created a crisis for native craftsmen and artists, who turned to secular patrons. One result of this was the flourishing of [[Scottish Renaissance painted ceilings]] and walls. Other forms of domestic decoration included tapestries and stone and wood carving. In the first half of the eighteenth century there was an increasing professionalisation and organisation of art. Large numbers of artists took the [[grand tour]] to Italy. The Academy of St. Luke was founded as a society for artists in 1729. It included among its members [[Allan Ramsay (artist)|Allan Ramsay]], who emerged as one of the most important British artists of the era.
==Devotional art== [[File:Margaret Tudor praying.jpg|thumb|160px|upright|A page from the [[Hours of James IV of Scotland]]]] {{See also|Christianity in Medieval Scotland|Scottish Reformation}} Devotional art acquired from the [[Netherlands]] in the later fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries included the images of St Catherine and St John brought to [[Dunkeld]]; [[Hugo van Der Goes]]'s altarpiece for the [[Trinity College Kirk|Trinity College Church in Edinburgh]], commissioned by [[James III of Scotland|James III]], and the work after which the Flemish [[Master of James IV of Scotland]] is named.<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9"/> There are also a relatively large number of elaborate devotional books from the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries, usually produced in the Netherlands and France for Scottish patrons. These include the prayer book commissioned by [[Robert Blackadder]], [[Bishop of Glasgow]], between 1484 and 1492<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9/> and the Flemish illustrated [[book of hours]], known as the [[Hours of James IV of Scotland]], given by [[James IV of Scotland|James IV]] to [[Margaret Tudor]] after 1503 and described by D. H. Caldwell as "perhaps the finest medieval manuscript to have been commissioned for Scottish use".<ref>D. H. Caldwell, ed., ''Angels, Nobles and Unicorns: Art and Patronage in Medieval Scotland'' (Edinburgh: National Museum of Scotland, 1982), p. 84.</ref>
Before the Reformation in the mid-sixteenth century the interiors of Scottish churches were often elaborate and colourful. Particularly in the north-east of the country there were highly decorated [[sacrament house]]s, like the ones surviving at Kinkell from 1524 and [[Deskford]] from 1541.<ref name=Whyte&Whyte1991p117>I. D. Whyte and K. A. Whyte, ''The Changing Scottish Landscape, 1500–1800'' (London: Taylor & Francis, 1991), {{ISBN|0-415-02992-9}}, p. 117.</ref> [[Funerary art|Monumental effigies]] in churches were usually fully coloured and gilded and dedicated to members of the clergy, knights and their wives. In contrast to England, where the fashion for stone-carved monuments gave way to [[monumental brass]]es, in Scotland they continued to be produced until the end of the Medieval period.<ref>R. Brydall, ''The Monumental Effigies of Scotland: from the Thirteenth to the Fifteenth Century'' (Kessinger Publishing, 1895, rpt. 2010) {{ISBN|1-169-23232-9}}.</ref><ref>K. Stevenson, ''Chivalry and Knighthood in Scotland, 1424–1513'' (Boydell Press, 2006), {{ISBN|1-84383-192-9}}, pp. 125–8.</ref> These include the very elaborate Douglas tombs in the town of [[Douglas, South Lanarkshire|Douglas]] and the tomb built for Alexander McLeod (d. 1528) at [[Rodel]] in Harris.<ref name=Whyte&Whyte1991p117/> Scotland's ecclesiastical art paid a heavy toll as a result of Reformation [[iconoclasm]], with the almost total loss of medieval stained glass, religious sculpture and paintings.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9/> The only significant surviving pre-Reformation stained glass in Scotland is a window of four roundels in the St. Magdalen Chapel of [[Cowgate]], [[Edinburgh]], completed in 1544.<ref name="West1985p55">T. W. West, ''Discovering Scottish Architecture'' (Botley: Osprey, 1985), {{ISBN|0-85263-748-9}}, p. 55.</ref> Wood carving can be seen at [[King's College, Aberdeen]] and [[Dunblane Cathedral]].<ref name=Scott1993p208/> In the West Highlands, where there had been a hereditary caste of monumental sculptors, the uncertainty and loss of patronage caused by the rejection of monuments in the Reformation meant that they moved into another branches of the Gaelic learned orders or took up other occupations. The lack of transfer of carving skills is noticeable in the decline in quality when gravestones were next commissioned from the start of the seventeenth century.<ref name=Dawson2007p131>J. E. A. Dawson, ''Scotland Re-Formed, 1488–1587'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-7486-1455-9}}, p. 131.</ref> According to N. Prior, the nature of the Scottish Reformation may have had wider effects, limiting the creation of a culture of public display and meaning that art was channelled into more austere forms of expression with an emphasis on private and domestic restraint.<ref>N. Prior, ''Museums and Modernity: Art Galleries and the Making of Modern Culture'' (Berg, 2002), {{ISBN|1-85973-508-8}}, p. 102.</ref>
==Portraiture== {{See also|Portrait painting in Scotland|Portrait painting}} [[File:James Stewart Earl of Moray.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[James Stewart, 1st Earl of Moray]] by [[Hans Eworth]]]] Around 1500, about the same time as in England, Scottish monarchs turned to the recording of royal likenesses in panel portraits, painted in oils on wood, perhaps as a form of political expression. In 1502 [[James IV of Scotland|James IV]] paid for delivery of portraits of the Tudor household, probably by the "Inglishe payntour" named "Mynours," who stayed in Scotland to paint the king and his new bride [[Margaret Tudor]] the following year.<ref name=Tittler2008p449>R. Tittler, "Portrait, politics and society", in R. Tittler and N. Jones, eds, ''A Companion to Tudor Britain'' (Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, 2008), {{ISBN|1-4051-3740-1}}, p. 449.</ref> "Mynours" was Maynard Wewyck, a Flemish painter who usually worked for Henry VII in London.<ref>M. Belozerskaya, ''Rethinking the Renaissance, Burgundian Arts Across Europe'' (Cambridge 2002), {{ISBN|978-1-107-60544-2}}, p. 159: J. W. Clark, 'Notes on the tomb of Margaret Beaufort,' ''Proceedings Cambridge Antiquarian Society'', 45 (1883), pp. 267–8.</ref> As in England, the monarchy may have had model portraits of royalty used for copies and reproductions, but the versions of native royal portraits that survive are generally crude by continental standards.<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9">J. Wormald, ''Court, Kirk, and Community: Scotland, 1470–1625'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1991), {{ISBN|0-7486-0276-3}}, pp. 57–9.</ref> Much more impressive are the works or artists imported from the continent, particularly the Netherlands, generally considered the centre of painting in the Northern Renaissance.<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9"/> The products of these connections included a fine portrait of [[William Elphinstone]].<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9>B. Webster, ''Medieval Scotland: the Making of an Identity'' (St. Martin's Press, 1997), {{ISBN|0-333-56761-7}}, pp. 127–9.</ref> It is one of the earliest representations of a Scottish subject to survive and was probably painted by a Scots artist using Flemish techniques.<ref name=Dawson2007pp55-6>J. E. A. Dawson, ''Scotland Re-Formed, 1488–1587'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-7486-1455-9}}, pp. 55–6.</ref> The tradition of royal portrait painting in Scotland was disrupted by the minorities and regencies it underwent for much of the sixteenth century. In his majority [[James V of Scotland|James V]] was probably more concerned with architectural expressions of royal identity.<ref name=Tittler2008p455-6/> Mary Queen of Scots had been brought up in the French court, where she was drawn and painted by major European artists, but she did not commission any adult portraits, with the exception of the joint portrait with her second husband [[Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley]]. This may have reflected an historic Scottish pattern, where [[heraldry|heraldic display]] or an elaborate tomb were considered more important than a portrait.<ref name=Dawson2007pp55-6/>
Portraiture began to flourish after the Reformation.<ref name=Tittler2008p455-6>R. Tittler, "Portrait, politics and society", in R. Tittler and N. Jones, eds, ''A Companion to Tudor Britain'' (Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, 2008), {{ISBN|1-4051-3740-1}}, pp. 455–6.</ref> There were anonymously painted portraits of important individuals, including one of [[James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell]] (1556).<ref name="Tittler2008p455-6"/> Artists from the Low Countries remained important. [[Hans Eworth]], who had been court painter to [[Mary I of England]], painted a number of Scottish subjects in the 1560s. His 1561 wedding portraits were miniatures commemorating the brief marriage of the earl of Bothwell and [[Jean Gordon, Countess of Bothwell|Jean Gordon]].<ref name=Dawson2007pp55-6/> He also painted [[James Stewart, 1st Earl of Moray]] in 1561 and two years later he painted a joint portrait of the young Darnley and his brother [[Charles Stuart, 1st Earl of Lennox|Charles Stuart]].<ref>E. K. Waterhouse, ''Painting in Britain: 1530 to 1790'' (Yale University Press, 5th edn., 1994), {{ISBN|0-300-05833-0}}, p. 32.</ref> [[George Seton, 7th Lord Seton|Lord Seton]], Master of the Royal Household commissioned two portraits in the Netherlands in the 1570s, one of himself and one a family portrait.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9/> A specific type of Scottish picture is the "vendetta portrait", designed to keep alive the memory of an atrocity. Examples include the ''Darlney memorial portrait'', which shows the young James IV kneeling at his murdered father's tomb and the lifesize portrait of the corpse of ''The Bonnie Early of Moray'' vividly showing the wounds received by [[James Stewart, 2nd Earl of Moray]] when he was killed by [[George Gordon, 1st Marquess of Huntly]] in 1592.<ref>E. K. Waterhouse, ''Painting in Britain: 1530 to 1790'' (Yale University Press, 5th edn., 1994), {{ISBN|0-300-05833-0}}, pp. 48–9.</ref>
[[File:BonnieEarlofMoray.jpg|thumb|upright=4|center|''The Bonnie Earl of Moray'', anonymous "vendetta portrait" of the murdered [[James Stewart, 2nd Earl of Moray]], 1592 (1591 [[Old Style and New Style dates|Old Style]])]]
[[File:John Baptist Medina Self Portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Self portrait by [[John Baptist Medina]]'' (c. 1698)]] There was an attempt to produce a series of portraits of Scottish kings in panel portraits, probably for the [[royal entry]] of the fifteen-year-old [[James VI of Scotland|James VI]] in 1579, which are Medieval in form. In James VI's personal reign, Renaissance forms of portraiture began to dominate.<ref name=Tittler2008p455-6/> He employed two Flemish artists, [[Arnold Bronckorst]] in the early 1580s and [[Adrian Vanson]] from around 1584 to 1602, who have left us a visual record of the king and major figures at the court.<ref name=Dawson2007pp55-6/> However, the [[Union of Crowns]] in 1603 removed a major source of artistic patronage in Scotland as James VI and his court moved to London. The result has been seen as a shift "from crown to castle", as the nobility and local lairds became the major sources of patronage.<ref name="Wormald1991p193">J. Wormald, ''Court, Kirk, and Community: Scotland, 1470–1625'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1991), {{ISBN|0-7486-0276-3}}, p. 193.</ref>
By the seventeenth century the fashion for portraiture had spread down the social order to [[laird]]s such as [[Sir Colin Campbell, 2nd Baronet|Colin Campbell of Glenorchy]] and [[John Napier|John Napier of Merchiston]].<ref name=Dawson2007pp55-6/> The first significant native artist was [[George Jamesone]] of Aberdeen (1589/90-1644), who, having trained in the Netherlands, became one of the most successful portrait painters of the reign of [[Charles I of England|Charles I]]. He trained the Baroque artist [[John Michael Wright]] (1617–94), who painted both Scottish and English subjects.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9>A. Thomas, ''The Renaissance'', in T. M. Devine and J. Wormald, ''The Oxford Handbook of Modern Scottish History'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2012), {{ISBN|0-19-162433-0}}, pp. 198–9.</ref> The Flemish-Spanish painter [[John Baptist Medina]] (1659–1710) came to Scotland in 1693 and became the leading Scottish portrait painter of his generation.<ref>M. Lynch, ed., ''The Oxford Companion to Scottish History'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2001), {{ISBN|0-19-211696-7}}, p. 136.</ref> Among his best known works are a group of about 30 oval bust-lengths, including a self-portrait, in [[Surgeons' Hall, Edinburgh]]. He trained his son, also John, and [[William Aikman (painter)|William Aikman]] (1682–1731), who became the leading portrait painter of the next generation.<ref>E. K. Waterhouse, ''Painting in Britain, 1530 to 1790'' (London: Penguin, 4th Edn, 1978), pp. 150–1.</ref> Aikman migrated to London in 1723, and from this point until the late eighteenth century, most Scottish painters of note followed him.<ref name=Waterhouse1994p300/>
==Domestic decoration== {{See also|Scottish castles|Estate houses in Scotland}} [[File:Painted ceiling from Rossend Castle.JPG|thumb|left|Painted ceiling from [[Rossend Castle]], [[Burntisland]]]] The loss of ecclesiastical patronage that resulted from the Reformation, created a crisis for native craftsmen and artists, who turned to secular patrons. One result of this was the flourishing of [[Scottish Renaissance painted ceilings]] and walls, with large numbers of private houses of burgesses, lairds and lords gaining often highly detailed and coloured patterns and scenes, of which over a hundred examples survive.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9/> These were undertaken by unnamed Scottish artists using continental pattern books that often led to the incorporation of humanist moral and philosophical symbolism, with elements that call on heraldry, piety, classical myths and allegory.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9/> The earliest surviving example is at the Hamilton palace of [[Kinneil House|Kinneil]], West Lothian, decorated in the 1550s for the then regent the [[James Hamilton, Duke of Châtellerault|James Hamilton, Earl of Arran]].<ref name=Dawson2007p290>J. E. A. Dawson, ''Scotland Re-Formed, 1488–1587'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-7486-1455-9}}, p. 290.</ref> Other examples include the ceiling at [[Prestongrange House]], undertaken in 1581 for Mark Kerr, Commendator of [[Newbattle]], and the long gallery at [[Pinkie House]], painted for [[Alexander Seton, 1st Earl of Dunfermline|Alexander Seaton]], Earl of Dunfermline in 1621.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9/>
Records also indicate that Scottish palaces were adorned by rich [[Scottish Royal tapestry collection|tapestries]], like those that depicted scenes from the ''[[Iliad]]'' and ''[[Odyssey]]'' set up for James IV at [[Holyrood Palace|Holyrood]].<ref name=Glendinningetal1996p14>M. Glendinning, R. MacInnes and A. MacKechnie, ''A History of Scottish Architecture: from the Renaissance to the Present Day'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1996), {{ISBN|0-7486-0849-4}}, p. 14.</ref> Some of this was undertaken by exclusive professional embroiders, but needlework was part of female education at all levels of society. Some of these tapestries were produced by noble ladies, such as the bed [[Window valance|valance]]s made by Katherine Ruthven for her marriage in 1551 to Campbell of Glenorchy. These are the oldest surviving examples of Scottish produced embroidery.<ref name=Dawson2007p178/> They display the couple's initials, arms and the story of Adam and Eve. A carpet designed to cover a table may be connected to the marriage of Katherine Oliphant, which has her initials, arms, biblical verses and (perhaps as a pun on her name) an elephant. Much of the needle work of the sixteenth century has been attributed, probably erroneously, to Mary, Queen of Scots. It is thought that she did contribute to the [[Oxburgh Hangings]] while imprisoned in England.<ref name=Dawson2007p178>J. E. A. Dawson, ''Scotland Re-Formed, 1488–1587'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-7486-1455-9}}, p. 178.</ref>
[[File:Stirling Head King James V.jpg|thumb|right|King [[James V of Scotland|James V]] in one of the [[Stirling Heads]]]] Although tradition of stone and wood carving in churches largely ended at the Reformation, it continued in royal palaces, the great houses of the nobility and even the humbler homes of lairds and burgesses.<ref>J. Warrack, ''Domestic Life in Scotland, 1488–1688: A Sketch of the Development of Furniture and Household Usage'' (1930, Forgotton books, reprint, 2012), pp. 76–82.</ref> The intricate lid of the fourteenth-century [[Bute mazer]], carved from a single piece of whale bone, was probably created in the early sixteenth century.<ref>H. Fothringham, ''Scottish Gold and Silver Work'' (London: Pelican, 2nd edn., 1999), {{ISBN|1-4556-1170-0}}, p. 54.</ref> At [[Stirling Castle]], stone carvings on the royal palace from the reign of [[James V of Scotland|James V]] are taken from German patterns,<ref>C. McKean, ''The Scottish Chateau'' (Sutton, 2nd edn., 2004), {{ISBN|0-7509-3527-8}}, p. 90.</ref> and, like the surviving carved oak portrait roundels from the King's Presence Chamber, known as the [[Stirling Heads]], they include contemporary, biblical and classical figures.<ref>J. Dunbar, ''The Stirling Heads'' (London: [[RCAHMS]]/[[HMSO]], 1975), {{ISBN|0-11-491310-2}}, p. 21.</ref> These, and the elaborate Renaissance fountain at [[Linlithgow Palace]] (c. 1538.), suggest that there was a workshop with an established connected with the court in the early sixteenth century.<ref name=Scott1993p208/> Some of the finest domestic wood carving is in the Beaton panels made for [[Arbroath Abbey]]<ref name=Scott1993p208>H. Scott, ed., ''Scotland: A Concise Cultural History'' (Mainstream, 1993), {{ISBN|1-85158-581-8}}, p. 208.</ref> and at [[Huntly Castle]], rebuilt for [[George Gordon, 1st Marquess of Huntly]] in the early seventeenth century, which focused on heraldic images. Their "[[Anti-popery|popish]]" overtones led to them being damaged by an occupying [[Covenanter]] army in 1640.<ref name=Glendinningetal1996p46>M. Glendinning, R. MacInnes and A. MacKechnie, ''A History of Scottish Architecture: from the Renaissance to the Present Day'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1996), {{ISBN|0-7486-0849-4}}, p. 46.</ref> From the seventeenth century, as domestic architecture for the nobility was increasingly for comfort, rather than fortification, there was elaborate use of carving in carved pediments, fireplaces, heraldic arms and classical motifs. Plasterwork also began to be used, often depicting flowers and cherubs.<ref name="West1985p68">T. W. West, ''Discovering Scottish Architecture'' (Botley: Osprey, 1985), {{ISBN|0-85263-748-9}}, p. 68.</ref> Richly carved decoration on ordinary houses was common in the period. There is also the heraldic carving, such as the royal arms at [[Holyrood Palace]], designed by the Dutch painter [[Jacob de Wet]] in 1677. The tradition of carving also survived in work like the carved stone panels in the garden of [[Edzell Castle]] (c. 1600), the now lost carving done for Edinburgh and Glasgow universities in the seventeenth-century and in the many elaborate sundials of the seventeenth century, like those at Newbattle.<ref name="Scott1993p208"/>
==Professionalisation of art== {{See also|Scottish Enlightenment}} [[File:JamesNorieSnrLandscape.jpg|thumb|upright=5|center|A [[Capriccio (art)|capriccio]] by James Nories senior (1684–1757), credited with originating the tradition of landscape painting in Scotland]] [[File:Allan Ramsay, Selbstportrait.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Self portrait by [[Allan Ramsay (painter)|Allan Ramsay]]]] The growing importance of royal art can be seen in the post of [[Painter and Limner]], created in 1702 for George Ogilvie. The duties included drawing pictures of the Monarch's person, his successors and members of the royal family, for the decoration of royal houses and palaces. However, from 1723 to 1823 the office was a [[sinecure]] held by members of the Abercrombie family, not necessarily connected with artistic ability.<ref>''The Laws of Scotland: Stair Memorial Encyclopaedia'', vol. 7 "The Crown", para 847.</ref> Many painters of the early part of the eighteenth century remained largely artisans, like the members of the Norie family, James (1684–1757) and his sons, Robert and the younger James, who painted the houses of the peerage with Scottish landscapes that were [[Capriccio (art)|capriccios]] or [[pastiche]]s of Italian and Dutch landscapes.<ref name=Baudino2011p153>I. Baudino, "Aesthetics and Mapping the British Identity in Painting", in A. Müller and I. Karremann, ed., ''Mediating Identities in Eighteenth-Century England: Public Negotiations, Literary Discourses, Topography'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2011), {{ISBN|1-4094-2618-1}}, p. 153.</ref> They tutored artists and have been credited with the inception of the tradition of Scottish landscape painting that would come to fruition from the late eighteenth century.<ref>E. K. Waterhouse, ''Painting in Britain, 1530 to 1790'' (London: Penguin, 4th Edn, 1978), p. 293.</ref> Italy became an important point of reference for Scottish artists, with many taking the [[Grand Tour]] there to paint, sample the art and learn from Italian masters.<ref>J. Wormald, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mFt2S33o8G8C&pg=PT376&dq=scottish+artists+italy&hl=En&ei=KQipT-rINemP4gTboeyOCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=scottish%20artists%20italy&f=false ''Scotland: A History''] (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005), {{ISBN|0-19-162243-5}}.</ref>
In 1729 there was an attempt to found a school of painting in Edinburgh as the Academy of St. Luke, named after the Renaissance [[Accademia di San Luca]] in Rome. Its president was George Marshall, a painter of [[still life|still lives]] and portraits, and its treasurer was the engraver Richard Cooper. Other members included Cooper's student Robert Strange, the two younger Nories, the portrait painters [[John Alexander (painter)|John Alexander]] (c. 1690-c. 1733) and [[Allan Ramsay (artist)|Allan Ramsay]] (1713–84).<ref>A. Smart, ''The Life and Art of Allan Ramsay'' (London: Taylor & Francis, 1951), p. 11.</ref> The success of the group was limited by its associations with [[Jacobitism]], with Strange printing bank notes for the rebels.<ref name="Mackieetal1991p202">J. D. Mackie, B. Lenman and G. Parker, ''A History of Scotland'' (London: Penguin, 1991), {{ISBN|0-14-013649-5}}, p. 311.</ref> Alexander was a great grandson of George Jamesone. He studied in London and Rome, returning to Edinburgh about 1720 where he painted the Baroque ''The Rape of Proserpine'', for the roof of a staircase at [[Gordon Castle]] and numerous portraits.<ref name=Waterhouse1994p300>E. K. Waterhouse, ''Painting in Britain: 1530 to 1790'' (Yale University Press, 5th edn., 1994), {{ISBN|0-300-05833-0}}, p. 330.</ref> Ramsay emerged as the most distinguished alumni of the academy. He studied in Sweden, London and Italy before basing himself in Edinburgh. There he established himself as a leading portrait painter to the Scottish nobility, before moving to London in 1757.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/490799/Allan-Ramsay "Allan Ramsey"], ''Encyclopædia Britannica'', retrieved 7 May 2012.</ref> He made occasional return visits to Edinburgh to undertake commissions for the nobility and gentry.<ref name=Waterhouse1994p300/>{{clear}}

Catalog'' | artist= | year=1962 | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] | museum=[[Russian Museum|State Russian Museum]] }} '''Autumn Exhibition of Leningrad artists of 1962''' ({{lang-ru|Осенняя выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1962 года}}) opened in [[Russian Museum|State Russian Museum]] become one of the largest Art Exhibition of 1962 in the USSR.
== History and Organization ==
For the organization and preparation of Exhibition was formed specially Exhibition Committee which consisted of 25 the most authoritative art-experts. Exhibition Catalog was published.<ref>''Осенняя выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1962 года. Каталог''. Л., Художник РСФСР, 1962.</ref> In total, the Exhibition displayed almost 600 works of art of painters, sculptors, graphics, artists of theater and cinema, masters of arts and crafts. At whole Exhibition attended over 350 artists of the Leningrad.
== Contributing Artists ==
[[File:Russian museam.JPG|thumb|340px|[[Russian Museum|''State Russian Museum'']]]]
In the largest Department of Painting were exhibited art works of 177 authors. There were [[Piotr Alberti]], [[Evgenia Antipova]], [[Taisia Afonina]], [[Sergei Babkov (painter)|Sergei Babkov]], [[Irina Baldina]], [[Nikolai Baskakov (painter)|Nikolai Baskakov]], [[Vsevolod Bazhenov]], [[Yuri Belov]], [[Dmitry Belyaev (artist)|Dmitry Belyaev]], [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], [[Nikolai Galakhov]], [[Ivan Godlevsky]], [[Vladimir Gorb]], [[Abram Grushko]], [[Alexei Eremin]], [[Mikhail Kaneev]], [[Maria Kleschar-Samokhvalova]], [[Maya Kopitseva]], [[Boris Korneev]], [[Alexander Koroviakov]], [[Victor Korovin]], [[Elena Kostenko]], [[Gevork Kotiantz]], [[Mikhail Kozell]], [[Engels Kozlov]], [[Marina Kozlovskaya]], [[Yaroslav Krestovsky]], [[Valeria Larina]], [[Boris Lavrenko]], [[Ivan Lavsky]], [[Anatoli Levitin]], [[Oleg Lomakin]], [[Gavriil Malish]], [[Boris Maluev]], [[Evsey Moiseenko]], [[Nikolai Mukho]], [[Piotr Nazarov]], [[Vera Nazina]], [[Mikhail Natarevich]], [[Yaroslav Nikolaev]], [[Dmitry Oboznenko]], [[Lev Orekhov]], [[Lia Ostrova]], [[Vladimir Ovchinnikov (painter)|Vladimir Ovchinnikov]], [[Sergei Ivanovich Osipov|Sergei Osipov]], [[Genrikh Pavlovsky]], [[Varlen Pen]], [[Nikolai Pozdneev]], [[Stepan Privedentsev]], [[Semion Rotnitsky]], [[Galina Rumiantseva]], [[Ivan Savenko]], [[Gleb Savinov]], [[Alexander Mikhailovich Semionov|Alexander Semionov]], [[Arseny Semionov]], [[Nadezhda Shteinmiller]], [[Elena Skuin]], [[Kim Slavin]], [[Alexander Ivanovich Sokolov|Alexander Sokolov]], [[Alexander Stolbov]], [[Alexander Tatarenko]], [[Victor Teterin]], [[Nikolai Timkov]], [[Mikhail Trufanov]], [[Yuri Tulin]], [[Boris Ugarov]], [[Ivan Varichev]], [[Anatoli Vasiliev]], [[Valery Vatenin]], [[Rostislav Vovkushevsky]], [[Vecheslav Zagonek]], [[Elena Zhukova]], and others most prominent painters of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad School]].<ref>''Осенняя выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1962 года. Каталог''. Л., Художник РСФСР, 1962.</ref>
In the Department of Sculptures were exhibited art works of 41 sculptors. Department of graphics presented a creation of 86 artists.
== Contributed Artworks ==
For the Exhibition were selected art works created in 1961-1962, also some earlier works. All they were exhibited in the first time. Some of them were subsequently found in the collections of Soviet Art museums, as well as domestic and foreign galleries and collectors.

Каталог''. Л., Художник РСФСР, 1962.</ref>
